origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Department of Political Science.

did.unittitle: Department of Political Science (University of Michigan) records 1910-2009 1970-2000
did.abstract: The Department of Political Science was established in 1910 under the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts; offers coursework in American politics, comparative politics, world politics and international relations, political theory, law and courts, and methodology. The collection spans from 1910-2009 with a bulk of the material from 1970-2000. These records document the administrative functioning of the department and contain committee meeting minutes, information on courses and degrees, departmental meeting minutes, information on faculty, various topical files, and audio-visual material.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred from the Department of Political Science in December 1996 and May/June 2000. An addition was made in 2013. (Donor No. 2184)

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Department of Political Science (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Although the Department of Political Science was not formally established until 1910, courses in what came to be known as the field of political science have been taught at the University of Michigan since 1860, when Thomas McIntyre Cooley began to offer classes on the Constitution within the Law Department. After 1865, courses in government were offered in the Department of History, reflecting the focus of history on political institutions, individuals, and events. Within this department, Charles Kendall Adams taught lecture courses in the growth of liberty in England and the history and characteristics of the Constitution of the United States. From 1872 to 1910, President James B. Angell taught classes in Public International Law and the History of Treaties which were available to students in both the Law Department and the Department of Literature, Science and the Arts (LS&A). In 1881, a School of Political Science was formed within LS&A with Adams as dean. The new school combined the curricula taught by these three men with other topics such as political economy, social science, sanitary science, comparative administrative law, and forestry administration. The school only lasted through the 1887-1888 academic year, however, dissolving as a result of administrative difficulties and the departures of Adams to Cornell in 1885 and temporarily of Cooley to the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1887.

Once the School of Political Science was discontinued, courses in this subject were again taken over by the history department. With the retirement of President Angell in 1909, it was determined that a new faculty member should be appointed to teach his courses and this process led to the establishment of a new department within LS&A. In 1910, the Department of Political Science was established with Jesse Siddall Reeves appointed as its first professor. Reeves taught courses in American Government, Municipal Government, Public International Law, and the History of American Diplomacy. The courses proved quite popular and faculty appointments and student enrollment increased for several years. Joseph Hayden was the first to receive a Ph.D. from the department in 1915. The Center for Political Studies was formally created in 1970 within the Institute of Social Research with Professor Miller serving as the first director. In 1976, President Gerald R. Ford was appointed as an adjunct professor and came to campus to give presentations on foreign policy. In 1990, the chair of the department, Jack Walker, died in a car crash, which caused the Undergraduate Affairs Conference to be renamed the Walker Conference.

In 1997 U.S. News and World Report ranked the department as number one in the field of American government and politics, and second for its overall program. The department currently teaches courses within six major fields of political science: American politics, comparative politics, world politics and international relations, political theory, law and courts, and methodology.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Department of Political Science document its administrative functions from 1910 to 2009 and the bulk of the records date from 1970 to 2009. The record group is divided into seven series: Committees, Correspondence, Course and Degree Information, Departmental Meetings, Faculty, Topical Files, and Audio-Visual.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Political Science.
controlaccess.subject: Political science--Study and teaching--Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Committees records (3.5 linear feet, 1972-2004) primarily include information from the Executive Committee, including meeting agendas and minutes, election results, memoranda, correspondence, and reports. For the years 1972-1982 the records are arranged chronologically by school year and are divided into five sections within each year: "Organization," "Agendas," "Minutes," "Documents," and "Miscellaneous." For the years 1989-1994, the records are arranged chronologically by month of the school year. Other committee information is included in the record group, most notably information on the activities of the Graduate Affairs Committee.

odd.p: (the following subdivisions are made within each school year: Organization, Agendas, Minutes, Documents, Miscellaneous)

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1.25 linear feet, 1972-1996) contains various communications between members of the department faculty and other faculty in the University as well as correspondence with people outside the University.

The Course and Degree Information series (1.5 linear feet, 1910-2009) contains course guides, handbooks, and various materials related to information about the department's courses and degree programs. Of particular note is the statistics on all students who have received a Ph.D. from the department from 1910 to 2009.

did.unittitle: UPSA (Undergraduate Political Science Association) Course Guides and Events 1991-1998

scopecontent.p: The Departmental Meetings series (1.0 linear foot, 1972-1988) contains the agendas, minutes, and attachments of the monthly meetings of the faculty and selected members of the graduate and undergraduate student associations of the department. The records are arranged chronologically. The departmental meetings typically involved debating matters directly affecting the department such as policies and procedures, faculty recommendations, and making final decisions on student and curricular matters.

The Faculty series (.75 linear feet, 1945-2004) primarily includes general information regarding the faculty of the department, faculty organizations, policies, and lists of faculty and their concentrations. Also included is data on faculty salaries.

The Topical File series (3 linear feet, 1910-2009) contains various records that pertain to issues and events occurring in the Department of Political Science. Of particular importance are the three files that contain the schedules, correspondence, and other materials relating to President Gerald R. Ford's several visits to campus as an adjunct professor in the Department of Political Science. The series also contains a large segment on the statistics of the department, such as the number of students enrolled, their gender and ethnicity, and their focus within the field of political science. Other files include departmental reviews, the renovation of Haven Hall, and copies of the departmental newsletter, The Satellite.

did.unittitle: Diversity in the Department of Political Science 1993

odd.p: (contact sheets, negatives are in UM. New and Information Services, Series C, Box C35)

did.unittitle: Irwin and Janet Robinson Scholarship Fund 1972
National Commission on the Public Service 1988
Report of Activities of the Department of Political Science 1954-1958
Research Center for Black Mental Health 1987

scopecontent.p: The Audio-Visual Material series (1.0 linear foot, 1943-1998) contains recordings of prominent lectures and awards ceremonies in the Department of Political Science. The most extensive portion of the collection is the audio recordings of the many lectures given by President Gerald R. Ford during his campus visits.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
For related material on political science, researchers may wish to consult the following collections held at the Bentley Library:
College of Literature, Science and the Arts
School of Political Science (Bimu C26/1)
Thomas McIntyre Cooley Papers, 1850-1898
James Kerr Pollack Papers, 1920-1968
Jesse Sidall Reeves Papers, 1853-1954
A.F.K. Organski Papers, 19591-1998
Alfred G. Meyer Papers, 1924-1998
Arthur W. Bromage Papers, 1917-1979
J. David Singer Papers, 1947-1997
Harold M. Door Papers, 1922-1973
Joseph Ralston Hayden Papers, 1854-1948
Warren E. Miller Papers, 1950-1980
Thomas H. Reed Papers, 1902-1971
Samuel James Eldersveld Papers, 1957-1959
Philip E. Converse papers, 1948-1989
Michel Oksenberg Papers, 1960-1992
Lynn W. Eley Papers, 1958-1963
Lionel H. Laing Papers, 1943-1962
Everett Somerville Brown, 1923-1955
George Ludwig Grassmuck, 1960-1971
Lawrence Preuss, 1945-1954
